description:
Schools and universities in Timor-Leste reopened on June 15 after being closed for more than two months due to the Covid-19 coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic. 

Students have to wear a mask. Each school has to prepare hand-washing facilities and ensure physical distancing

Youth and sports minister, Dulce de Jesus Soares, said more than 940 elementary and junior high schools needed masks and that the ministry was trying to address the shortfall.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
During the state of emergency (28 March-26 April), all school activities are suspended on a face-to-face basis and the facilities of educational, education and vocational training establishments are closed, and teachers and students are prohibited from staying in the premises. Distance learning should be promoted through the means of information and communication in this period. 

UPDATE: 
Reported on 11 June, as of 15 June schools will reopen with strict social distancing requirements. Classes will have a max 20 students and masks, handwashing and social distancing will be required. UPDATE: As reported on June 11, from June 15 schools will reopen with strict social distancing requirements in place.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)

description:
On July 27th, 2020, Timor Leste announced the initiative “Resume Learning Process Safely” at a school in Dili. The initiative, led by the Ministry of Education, Youth, and Sport (MEJD) and the UNICEF, aims to help schools to establish protocols in order to guarantee a safe reopening.

The “Resume Learning Process Safely” initiative, which includes an awareness campaign for the prevention of COVID-19 and the distribution of protective and hygiene equipment, relies on funding from the Government of Japan and the Asian Development Bank, and with the contribution of other entities.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 27 2020, the Timor Leste government announces national state of disaster.

On March 27 2020, the Timor Leste government announces national state of disaster. The original quarantine was set to last until April 26, it has been extended to May 27 2020, then renewed again until June 26, when it finally ended UPDATE: The original quarantine was set to last until April 26, it has been extended to May 27 2020, then renewed again until June 26, when it finally ended

On March 27 2020, the Timor Leste government announces national state of disaster. This state of emergency has been renewed until May 27. UPDATE: The original quarantine was set to last until April 26, it has been extended to May 27 2020.
link: NA ; http://www.tatoli.tl/en/2020/04/28/covid-19-president-lu-olo-extends-state-of-emergency/ ; Tatoli ; Covid-19: President Lú-Olo Extends State of Emergency

description: Prime Minister Taur  Matan  Ruak presented the draft Government Decree, approved by the Council of Ministers, on the Measures for Implementing the Renewal of the Declaration of the State of Emergency enacted by decree of the President of the Republic No. 32/2020, of April 27, to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic. It was originally due to expire on 26 April. UPDATE: On April 27 2020, the Timor Leste Government extended the State of Emergency indefinitely. It was originally due to expire on 26 April.

Timor-Leste will spend another 30 days under the state of emergency decree – subject to presidential approval. The state of emergency originally ended on 27 May. This was due to the worrying situation across the border in Indonesian, West Papua.

Timor-Leste will spend another 30 days under the state of emergency decree – subject to presidential approval. The state of emergency originally ended on 27 May. This was due to the worrying situation across the border in Indonesian, West Papua. 

UPDATE:

As of 25 June, the state of emergency will NOT be extended a third time, but will end on 26 June at midnight local time. Additionally, the Interministerial Commission has decided that the coordination powers of measures to combat COVID-19, will be passed on to the Ministry of Health in coordination with the CIGC and other relevant Ministries. UPDATE: Reported by the Timor Leste Government in 25 June: The state of emergency in Timor Leste was extended twice. It began on 28 March and will not be renewed once it ends on 26 June 2020. Additionally, the Interministerial Commission (that was overseeing Covid-19 measures) has decided that the President of the Republic will not be asked to extend the state of emergency and the coordination powers of measures to combat COVID-19, will be passed on to the Ministry of Health in coordination with the CIGC and other relevant Ministries.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Timor-Leste will spend another 30 days under the state of emergency decree – subject to presidential approval. The state of emergency originally ended on 27 May. This was due to the worrying situation across the border in Indonesian, West Papua. UPDATE: Timor-Leste will end a nationwide state of emergency at 2359 June 26 amid reduced coronavirus disease (COVID-19) activity.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Timor Leste announced on August 5 the return of the state of Emergency. Previously, it had ended in June after no cases were reported. Sadly, a new COVID-19 case was reported and the state of emergency will start on August 6 and be valid until September 4.

Timor Leste announced on August 5 the return of the state of Emergency. Previously, it had ended in June after no cases were reported. Sadly, a new COVID-19 case was reported and the state of emergency will start on August 6 and be valid until September 4. 

This was extended again until 4 October. UPDATE: The state of emergency was extended until 4 October.

Timor Leste announced on August 5 the return of the state of Emergency. Previously, it had ended in June after no cases were reported. Sadly, a new COVID-19 case was reported and the state of emergency will start on August 6 and be valid until September 4. 

This was initially extended once until October 5 and then again until November 3 2020. UPDATE: This state of emergency was extended again on 5 October for an additional 30 days, expiring November 3 2020.

Timor Leste announced on August 5 the return of the state of Emergency. Previously, it had ended in June after no cases were reported. Sadly, a new COVID-19 case was reported and the state of emergency will start on August 6 and be valid until September 4. 

This policy has been extended for a third time for an addition 30 days, now up until 3 December 2020. UPDATE: This initial state of emergency has been extended for a third time. It was extended from 4 November until 3 December the authorities in Timor Leste announced on 29 October.

Timor-Leste imposed entry restrictions for non-nationals who have recently traveled to China as of Saturday, February 8, amid the ongoing coronavirus (2019-nCoV) outbreak. Under the new restrictions, individuals who have traveled to Hubei province (China) over the last four weeks will be denied entry, and individuals who have traveled to other provinces in China may be denied entry unless they present a medical report issued by an internationally recognized medical institution and an accompanying photograph. Those found to have visited China in the last four weeks after arriving in Timor-Leste may be subject to quarantine or return to their last port of departure.
type_sub_cat: Health Certificates
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
All foreign nationals are no longer able to enter Timor Leste. 

The prohibition provided for in the preceding paragraph does not apply to foreigner nationals who were born in Timor-Leste territory and who usually reside here or who are the legal representatives of Timorese minors or third- country nationals who are legal residents of Timor-Leste over whom they exercise parental authority or ensure their support and education. UPDATE: On 28 March, the Timorese government announced a state of emergency, part of which declared that no foreigners would be allowed to enter Timor Leste. This ends the policy.
type_sub_cat: Health Certificates
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Timor-Leste imposed entry restrictions for non-nationals who have recently traveled to China as of Saturday, February 8, amid the ongoing coronavirus (2019-nCoV) outbreak. Under the new restrictions, individuals who have traveled to Hubei province (China) over the last four weeks will be denied entry, and individuals who have traveled to other provinces in China may be denied entry unless they present a medical report issued by an internationally recognized medical institution and an accompanying photograph. Those found to have visited China in the last four weeks after arriving in Timor-Leste may be subject to quarantine or return to their last port of departure. 

This policy ends when Timor Leste bans all incoming passengers, effective from 28 March UPDATE: This policy ended when Timor Leste began banning all incoming passengers.

description:
Announced on April 24, the Timor Leste government announced that three Indonesia-Timor-Leste border gates in Indonesian East Nusa Tenggara province's districts of Timor Tengah Utara, Malacca and Belu, reopened with strict health protocol procedures, a local official said.

"This policy also applies to the five cross-border gates in the districts of Wini, Motamasin, Napan, Turiskain and Haumeni Ana with strict security procedures from the Indonesian military and the country's customs task force. 

These border gates will open only on Wednesdays from 9-11am. All other border to Timor Leste are closed.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: The Timorese Government changed the rules on the country's land borders, within the scope of covid-19, and started to prohibit the entry of goods from West Timor (Indonesia) on June 08.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Prohibition of entry of foreigners into national territory:a) The prohibition shall not apply to foreign nationals who are already in national territory, the ones who were born in Timorese territory and habitually reside there and those who work on the oil platforms located in the Timor Seab) In duly justified cases (namely, defense of national interest or convenience of service), the Prime Minister of Timor-Leste may authorize the entry of foreigners in national territoryc) For the purpose of transportation or release of imported goods, foreign citizens are not subject to the authorization referred to in paragraph b) being, however, restricted to the international zones of sea ports, airports or land border posts and for the time strictly necessary for the completion of the procedures for delivery or release of goods UPDATE: The government of Timor-Leste’s “State of Emergency,” which went into effect March 28 and was twice extended and expired on June 26. This meant that the ban on all foreign arrivals, aside from Timorese people, is still in place.
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
The Timorese Government changed the rules on the country's land borders, within the scope of covid-19, and started to prohibit the entry of goods from West Timor (Indonesia) on June 08. From August 2, Timor is strengthening policing and border control as a preventive measure for covid-19.

 UPDATE: The Timorese Government changed the rules on the country's land borders, within the scope of covid-19, and started to prohibit the entry of goods from West Timor (Indonesia) on June 08. Now, since the beginning of August, more specifically August 2, Timor is increasing the number of policemen on the border.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)
link: NA ; http://noticias.sapo.tl/portugues/info/artigo/1534409.html ; Sapo ; COVID-19: Timor-Leste vai aumentar postos de policiamento na fronteira

description: As part of the renewed state of emergency in Timor Leste which lasts from 6 August until 4 September, all persons wishing to leave the country will be subject to health controls, in particular by measuring body temperatures or other means of diagnosis. All individuals who have any of the following symptoms – body temperature higher than 37.5 degrees Celsius, cough, sore throat, cold, and respiratory distress or shortness of breath – are prohibited from boarding buses, ships, or aircrafts except in cases of medical evacuation.
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On 12 August the Timor Leste government announced that they would open the border once every seventeen (17) days in order to control the number of people in quarantine facilities. Previously the policy had been to open the border for 2 hours every week. This change has come about because the government quarantine facilities have reached capacity of 400.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Announced on April 24, the Timor Leste government announced that three Indonesia-Timor-Leste border gates in Indonesian East Nusa Tenggara province's districts of Timor Tengah Utara, Malacca and Belu, reopened with strict health protocol procedures, a local official said.

"This policy also applies to the five cross-border gates in the districts of Wini, Motamasin, Napan, Turiskain and Haumeni Ana with strict security procedures from the Indonesian military and the country's customs task force. 

This policy ended on 12 August when the government decided to only open the border once every 17 days. 

These border gates will open only on Wednesdays from 9-11am. All other border to Timor Leste are closed. UPDATE: Original policy stated that the land border between Indonesia and Timor Leste would open for 2 hours every wednesday. On 12 August this policy ended and now the border will now only open every 17 days due to overcrowding in quarantine facilities.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
The Timorese Government changed the rules on the country's land borders, within the scope of covid-19, and started to prohibit the entry of goods from West Timor (Indonesia) on June 08. 

On the beginning of August it strengthened border policing and now, from August 19 on, it is allowing goods and people for a limited amount of time on a specific agenda. UPDATE: The Timorese Government changed the rules on the country's land borders, within the scope of covid-19, and started to prohibit the entry of goods from West Timor (Indonesia) on June 08. From August 2, Timor is strengthening policing and border control as a preventive measure for covid-19.

 UPDATE 1: The Timorese Government changed the rules on the country's land borders, within the scope of covid-19, and started to prohibit the entry of goods from West Timor (Indonesia) on June 08. Now, since the beginning of August, more specifically August 2, Timor is increasing the number of policemen on the border.

UPDATE 2: On August 19, the Timorese Government decided to limit the number of people entering the land border, allowing it to open only every 17 days. In the case of goods transport, the borders will be open for two hours every Tuesday.
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 4 September the US embassy in Timor Leste reported that US citizens (likely all foreigners) are allowed to enter Timor Leste if they can prove they do not have covid-19. Travelers must seek and receive approval to enter Timor-Leste prior to their entry. The pre-approval request, along with a negative COVID-19 PCR test result, should be submitted to the nearest Timorese Embassy or Consulate or to the Consular Directorate of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation of Timor-Leste.
type_sub_cat: Health Certificates
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
On 27 March Timor Leste banned the arrived of foreign nations. Exceptions for legal residents or those transporting required goods. 

Update: As of 4 September, foreign nationals can enter if they present a valid negative test result UPDATE: This policy appears to have ended. The US embassy announced on 4 September that US citizens (probably all foreign passengers) can enter Timor Leste if they present a valid negative test result. They must then isolate for 14 days.
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: The government of Timor Leste will develop a tracking system for COVID-19, announced 20 April.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As part of the renewed state of emergency in Timor Leste which runs from 6 August to 4 September, COVID-19 testing is required of anyone who enters the national territory and presents any of the symptoms: body temperature higher than 37.5 degrees Celsius, cough, sore throat, cold, and respiratory distress or shortness of breath. If they are diagnosed with COVID-19, they are obliged to undergo therapeutic isolation.

Vera  Cruz  Community Health Centre would  be  designated as the  Isolation  facility  and  FDTL  Metinaro  as  the  Quarantine  facility.  A  joint MoH-WHO  team   conducted  a  site  assessment  of  Vera  Cruz so that  this  facility  can  be upgraded quickly to serve as a treatment centre for suspected and confirmed cases of Covid-19.

description: During the pandemic, the Government of Timor Leste will subsidize the maritime transport of goods to and from Atauro and Oecussi (ports) and it will extend unloading from the port to a 24-hour basis. This will prevent delays in the distribution of essential supplies and food. Announced on 20 April.

description:
USAID has allocated $1.1 million through the WHO and contractor JSI for “training and technical support” to help Timor-Leste with Covid-19, the embassy said.

“The funding will help the government prepare laboratory systems, activate case-finding and event-based surveillance, support technical experts for response and preparedness, risk communication, infection prevention and control, and more,” the embassy said in a statement. Announced on 29 April.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Announced 18 May, 30 handwashing stations have now been installed by Australia’s PARTISIPA program in partnership with the Ministry of Public Works of Timor Leste. The stations have been set up in ten municipalities across Timor-Leste.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Materials
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Reported on 1 June, there is a requirement to wear masks in public places in Timor Leste.
type_sub_cat: Masks

description: Reported 30 June in Timor Leste: Over 40 health workers comprising doctors, nurses, midwives, and health administrators of Viqueque municipality underwent hand hygiene training. This is a part of the month-long campaign by the MoH, the Timor-Leste nursing association and WHO to reinforce hand hygiene not only in the context of COVID-19 but also to attain better health outcomes overall and strengthen infection prevention and control (IPC) in health facilities and district health office
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Timor Leste was provided 30 android tablets pre-installed with Flow Monitoring software to the Timor-Leste Border Police force for COVID-19 mobility surveillance and data collection in the border districts. In addition, 40 BorderPolice force personnelwere also trained on the use of kobo toolbox for flow monitoring. Supported by WHO and USAID
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

type_sub_cat: Doctors

description:
Posted on 19 July, a new quarantine facility at Metinaro Military Base in Timor Leste was opened. 

With assistance from Australia’s Defence Cooperation Program, the F-FDTL has transformed an accommodation block into a temporary quarantine facility for F-FDTL members. With this new facility, the F-FDTL is taking steps to make sure they are prepared in case any soldiers need to be isolated to protect their family, colleagues or friends.
type_sub_cat: Temporary Quarantine Centers
enforcer: Military,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 22 the government of Timor Leste announced 100 thousand new face masks for the Timorese population, a partnership with the oil company 'Timor Resources'
type_sub_cat: Masks
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 24, Australian Ambassador Peter Roberts joined the Vice Minister for Education, Youth and Sports of Timor Leste, H.E. António Guterres to launch the distribution of back to school hygiene packages for basic education schools in all municipalities in Timor-Leste - together with the Australia - Timor-Leste Partnership for Human Development Australia Timor-Leste, Plan International Timor-Leste, Alola Foundation, UNICEF and Care International.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Materials
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Dili’s National Health Laboratory has begun reporting test results for coronavirus independently for this first time, without the need for “verification” at a secondary site. The NHL had partnered with Australian’s Menzies School of Health Research, but beginning from the week of 4 May, the lab no longer had to send tests to Darwin, Australia, but could be processes and get results locally. A very small amount of tests will still be sent to Darwin for validation. The Australian government claimed that this local testing capability is a result of funding provided by Australia to grow Timor Leste's lab facilities and capabilities. Reported on 9 May 2020.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The US embassy reported on 4 September that Timorese citizens and foreign nationals can obtain COVID-19 testing at the National Hospital, free of charge. Those seeking to test should call the COVID-19 hotline at +670-7556-0000 via WhatsApp first to receive further guidance on scheduling testing, (or other COVID-19 related questions), or call 119 if with COVID-19-like symptoms. Fees for testing may be imposed and those seeking testing should confirm the cost when scheduling an appointment.

Anyone who doesn't work in one of these fields 
Health and patient transport services
Security services
Civil protection services
Water and sanitation
Electricity production, transportation and distribution 
and those who do not have to attend their workplace in person should voluntarily isolate themselves in their homes.

Timor Leste's government approved a draft Decree-Law on the Legal Regime of Epidemiological Surveillance and Sanitary Surveillance on June 17, 2020. This diploma aims to provide epidemiological and health surveillance authorities with a range of measures appropriate for the protection and promotion of public health, both in times of normality as well as in emergency circumstances, without prejudice to the special regime of states of constitutional exception. The Decree-Law aims to ensure the mechanisms of protection of public health, seeking to avoid and neutralize risks of dissemination and spread of diseases in the population.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: As of June 27, Timor Leste's Ministry of Health and Integrated Crisis Management Center (CIGC) will manage the country's COVID-19 response.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers

description: Announced 30 June, The Prime Minister’s of Timor Leste's Office officially dissolved the “Integrated Centre for Crisis Management” and handed over the COVID-19 response, management,and coordination to the Ministry of Health(MoH). The Prime Minister in a statement said, “We appreciate the support offered UN agencies, other partners, and embassies.The response to COVID-19 is not one person or one entity’s job or responsibility, it require collective effort –from all of society. It is also imperative that everyone adheres to the preventive measures recommended by the MoH and WHO.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers

description:
As of June 27, Timor Leste's Ministry of Health and Integrated Crisis Management Center (CIGC) will manage the country's COVID-19 response. 

Reported on June 30, the Prime Minister’s Office officially dissolved the “Integrated Centre for Crisis Management” and handed over the COVID-19 response, management,and coordination to the Ministry of Health (MoH). UPDATE: The Prime Minister’s Office officially dissolved the “Integrated Centre for Crisis Management” and handed over the COVID-19 response, management,and coordination to the Ministry of Health(MoH). Announced on 30 June.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Timor Leste's Council of Minister approved on July 29, 2020, a package of four short-term measures to mitigate the impacts of the economic crisis resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic, proposed by the Commission for the Elaboration of the Economic Recovery Plan, led by the former Minister of Finance, Rui Augusto Gomes.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Existing government entity given new powers
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Licenses and authorizations, including visas granted to foreigners living and working in Timor-Leste, will remain valid for as long as these State of Emergency measures remain in force, regardless of the stated expiration date (28 March to 26 April 2020)
type_text: visas granted to foreigners living and working in Timor-Leste, will remain valid for as long as these State of Emergency measures remain in force

description: Timor Leste creates a covid-19 salary supplement for those working during the period of the state of emergency. The supplement will be between $5 and $25 US dollars depending on the estimated risk to the individual.
type_text: Supplement for those working during the state of emergency

description: An Australian Government funded aid project addressing gender-based violence is cooperating with the Timor Leste government to support women and children who are at risk of increased violence during the coronavirus period. This includes drafting guidance with the Ministry of Social Solidarity on receiving clients during the crisis, establishing a reception center for monitoring all new shelter clients during a 14-day quarantine period, and providing additional funding to improve water and hygiene in shelters.
type_text: Australian Government-funded aid organsation is working with the Timor Leste government to adjust shelter services for women and children who are victims of family violence during the pandemic.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 2 April, parliament approved $250 million from the country's Petroleum Fund ($400 was originally requested).

The prime minister (PM) of Timor-Leste withdrew his resignation on Wednesday (April 8), saying he would stay in power to oversee the battle against the coronavirus pandemic as the government approved a US$250 million (S$356 million) fund to fight it. The PM had resigned in February, after repeatedly failing to pass a budget for 2020, but agreed to stay on until a new government was formed.
type_text: PM of Timor Leste agrees to stay in the role for the duration of Coronavirus after originally resigning in Feb 2020.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Australia and the United States are co-ordinating their efforts to help Pacific and south-east Asian countries survive the coronavirus pandemic. Australia will take the lead and focus on helping Indonesia, Timor-Leste and the south-west Pacific.
type_text: International aid from US and Australia to support Asia and the Pacific during the pandemic. Including Timor Leste

description:
Reported on 16 April, in addition to $100.7 million in promised aid, the Australian Government Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has commenced a series of efforts to support the country.

Seasonal Timorese workers in Australia have had their visas extended to lessen the burden on their country's health system.

DFAT has repatriated nine Timorese doctors from Fiji to bolster local health services and an additional $10 million in aid has been earmarked for the country to address the emerging impacts of COVID-19.

The Australian Federal Police have also helped establish temporary police stations at quarantine facilities. UPDATE: In addition to $100.7 million in promised aid, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has commenced a series of efforts to support the country.  Seasonal Timorese workers in Australia have had their visas extended to lessen the burden on their country's health system.  DFAT has repatriated nine Timorese doctors from Fiji to bolster local health services and an additional $10 million in aid has been earmarked for the country to address the emerging impacts of COVID-19.  The Australian Federal Police have also helped establish temporary police stations at quarantine facilities.
type_text: International aid from US and Australia to support Asia and the Pacific during the pandemic. Including Timor Leste

description: the Government of Timor Leste will purchase a 3-month emergency supply of rice to offset potential shortages during the pandemic, announced on 20 April as part of broader stimulus package.
type_text: The government of Timor Leste will stockpile rice in case of shortages.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Government will implement a universal cash transfer system that will provide a monthly basic income to over 214,000 households. This is expected to last 3 months. It will also subsidize the payment of wages of formal sector employees who may be quarantined or staying at home during the pandemic, with the Government contributing up to 60% of the wage cost. This will stabilize employment and enable businesses to continue to employ their essential staff.
type_text: Enacting a universal basic income for over 200,000 people during the pandemic.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Government Of Timor Leste will partially waive the payment of electricity bills ($15 per month, announced 20 April). It will also waive the payment of water bills, social security contributions (by both workers and employees), and rent on state properties. The measures include a considerable credit program, featuring reduced interest rates, credit guarantees for importers of essential goods, and emergency loans, to avoid bankruptcies, keep businesses open, and support households resolve their financial difficulties.
type_text: Government will waive the payment of some utility bills, there will be a substantial credit program, emergency loans and other economic measures.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Timor Leste government will provide stipends to over 4,200 Timorese students living overseas, often in trying circumstances, while students in Timor-Leste will receive internet subsidies to study online. Announced 20 April.
type_text: Stipends to students studying overseas and support to Timorese students studying now online.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Timor-Leste government has allocated $63.6 million in financial aid for some 318,302 families struggling with the COVID-19 downturn.The families will each receive US $100 per month, for up to three months.

The money will come from the $150 million COVID-19 Fund, approved by the National Parliament in April, and overseen by the Integrated Crisis Management Centre (CIGC).

Reported 25 June: Timor Leste, has decided to extend, for another month, the contract with the airline Air North (Australian airline), which since April 10 2020 carries out regular flights to Timor-Leste, allowing to maintain an air transit route, in order to ensure the supply of medicines and equipment necessary for the prevention and combat of COVID-19 and also the supply of essential goods fundamental to the life of the population and national companies.
type_text: Essential supply chains (eg food and medications)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 1st the Council of Ministers of Timor Leste announced an agreement with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on a financial contribution from the Asia-Pacific Disaster Response Fund, valued at US$ 1 million, to support the population affected by the COVID-19, in particular in programs related to food security.
type_text: On July 1, Timor Leste's Council of Ministers gave full powers to Finance Minister Fernando Hanjan to sign an agreement with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on a financial contribution of one million US dollars, from the Asia-Pacific Disaster Response Fund, to support the population affected by COVID-19, in particular in food security-related programs. The agreement provides for the financial contribution to be used to buy food from national farmers and to distribute it to the most vulnerable families. The program will be implemented by the United Nations in coordination with the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Announced 1 September, the Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs (MCAE), Joaquim Amaral, revealed that the Government will assign “basic staple food” vouchers valued at the amount of $25 U.S.

“The maximum amount of [purchase voucher] is 25 U.S. dollars. But If certain people who receive it feels they do not require this, they can deliver the voucher to others who needed the most”, Mr.Amaral said.

According to him, the “basic staple basket”, aims to buy the products from the national economic market.

March 5 2020 the EU-UN Spotlight Initiative was launched in Timor Leste, allocating 1 million dollars to the prevention of violence against women. The funding would go towards technical assistance, public awareness campaigns and support for local civil society groups to prevent violence and abuse. While this initiative was already happening, it appears that it has come at a opportune time when domestic violence figures are rising around the world during the pandemic.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: The Ministry of Health of Timor Leste launched, on April 25, 2020, at the Media Center of the Integrated Crisis Management Center, a new chatbot instant messaging service through WhatsApp with information about COVID-19. For those with no internet on their phones, the information will be relayed via text message.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: Timor Leste's MoH with support from WHO is carrying out advocacy and community engagement and active surveillance targeting community leaders in the border district of Oecusse.The advocacy and community engagement sessions are designed to sensitize the communities on COVID-19 preventive measures. This activity is financially supported by USAID.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 27, Timor Leste announced that all people entering the country, all those infected with Covid-19 and all those under surveillance by health authorities must go into mandatory confinement at a hotel or in their home.

target_geog_level: All countries

description: International passengers will have to undergo 14-day mandatory quarantine upon arrival in Timor Leste. UPDATE: All international passengers will have to enter mandatory 14-day quarantine after the state of emergency ends on 26 June. This policy is ongoing.

description: International passengers will have to undergo 14-day mandatory quarantine upon arrival in Timor Leste. UPDATE: All international passengers will have to enter mandatory 14-day quarantine after the state of emergency ends on 26 June. This policy is ongoing.

description: As part of the renewed state of emergency in Timor Leste, individuals who are infected with COVID-19 or who are under the supervision of health authorities will remain in compulsory confinement for 14 days or until medical discharge in a health establishment, in their own residence, or in a state isolation center.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: As part of the renewed state of emergency in Timor Leste, individuals who are infected with COVID-19 or who are under the supervision of health authorities will remain in compulsory confinement for 14 days or until medical discharge in a health establishment, in their own residence, or in a state isolation center.

description:
On March 27, Timor Leste announced that all people entering the country, all those infected with Covid-19 and all those under surveillance by health authorities must go into mandatory confinement at a hotel or in their home. 

Announced on 6 August, this policy would remain in place over the duration of the new state of emergency running until September 4. UPDATE: on August 6, the Timor Leste government reinstated a state of emergency running until 4 September. This extends the policy of mandatory quarantine for all persons arriving in the country. They can quarantine in their respective residences subject to the approval of the Ministry of Health.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Published 29 June, but originally written for May: local markets in several municipalities have reopened, except in Covalima and other areas close to the Indonesian border. This will address some of the issues of food insecurity in these areas.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description: During the term of the state of emergency, the Members of the Government and the executive bodies of public legal persons included in the indirect administration of the State identify the human resources strictly necessary to ensure the functioning, under minimum services, of public services which they run, in order to ensure the functioning of public administration and the provision, to citizens and businesses, of goods and services which are urgent or which cannot be delayed
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government

description: Announced 28 March, by the government of Timor Leste: Locations where public services continue to operate shall ensure that there is a minimum distance of one metre between persons and provide the necessary means so users and staff can wash their hands before entering the building
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Unspecified public facilities
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions atttached

description:
Announced on 28 March by Timor Leste, During the term of the state of emergency, the Members of the Government and the executive bodies of public legal persons included in the indirect administration of the State identify the human resources strictly necessary to ensure the functioning, under minimum services, of public services which they run, in order to ensure the functioning of public administration and the provision, to citizens and businesses, of goods and services which are urgent or which cannot be delayed.

Officials exempted from their duty to appear in their respective services shall remain contactable by telephone and present themselves at the services where they usually provide their professional activity whenever they are summoned by the hierarchical superior.

Where possible, human resources should be allowed to provide professional activity on a non-face-to-face basis and through new communication and information technologies.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: During the duration of the state of emergency (28 March-26 April), collective passenger transport is suspended
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Dili Archdiocese suspends Masses in Timor Leste after the first coronavirus case in the country on March 21 for a week.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Dili Archdiocese suspends Masses in Timor Leste after the first coronavirus case in the country on March 21 for a week. After that, the deadline has been postponed until, finally, the churches reopened on May 28. UPDATE: The resumption of Masses, under continuing health protocols, comes after no new Covid-19 cases were reported in the last two weeks.The decision by the bishops of the predominantly Catholic country was announced on May 28, two months after churches were ordered closed following the discovery of the country’s first Covid-19 case on March 21.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 3 Timor Leste's government annouced that it was suspending all flights (domestic and international) to its capital, Dili. On July 13 the domestic flights ONLY were allowed back. UPDATE: On April 03, Timor Leste's government banned all flights (national and international). On July 13 it allowed domestic flights to normalize.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
type_text: No flights are allowed from April 03. Domestic or international, it does not matter.

description: During the duration of the state of emergency (28 March-26 April), collective passenger transport is suspended in Timor Leste. UPDATE: Small mini-busses will be able to carry max. 5 people in a slow resumption of public transport in Timor Leste. All transport was suspended on 29 March.

As part of the state of emergency, everyone must wash or sanitise their hands before entering commercial establishments and the premises of service providers, wear a mask that protects their mouth and nose, and maintain a distance of 1 metre from others. This applies to stores, markets and other venues.
People must wash their hands before entering buildings. UPDATE: The instruction to wash hands before entering buildings has been extended beyond the end of the state of emergency on 26 June.

As part of the renewed state of emergency in Timor Leste that runs from 6 August to 4 September, preventative measures at social activities must be taken, including where all persons are required to wear a protective mask covering their mouth and nose, wash their hands regularly, and maintain a safe distance of at least 1.5 meters from others.

description:
As part of the renewed state of emergency in Timor Leste that runs from 6 August to 4 September, preventative measures at social activities must be taken, including where all persons are required to wear a protective mask covering their mouth and nose, wash their hands regularly, and maintain a safe distance of at least 1.5 meters from others.

This policy has been extended along with the state of emergency until at least 3 December. UPDATE: This policy of social distancing was automatically extended when the state of emergency was extended 3 times until 3 December.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
